ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: discrete math
I learned how to write proofs more rigorously and a bit of graph theory.
I learned some foundational math in a broad range, and graph theory.
Writing proofs, counting, relations, combinatorics, graph theory, and trees.
Discrete mathematics
Through this class I mainly learned what graphs, trees, and sets are and how to use apply them. I also gained a deeper understanding of mathematical proofs.
graph theory, set theory, counting
This course helps develop theoretical problem solving and proof-writing skills.

There's a lot that I learned during this course. In fact, it is the most mathematically enlightening course I've taken. I've learned how to better read math textbooks, how to solve completely foreign problems, how to explain my thinking in a logical manner, and how to write proofs through trial and error. I discovered tons of math notation taking this course and, importantly, use mathematical induction in the majority of my proofs.
Lectures seemed pretty dull. Supposed to be a course about proof writing, but lectures didn't help to teach that

Combinatorics and graph theory require a different approach than linear algebra and other introductory math classes, which can sometimes be challenging but also rewarding. It requires a lot more intuition and working through examples on pen and paper, proofs often felt like ingenious magic tricks, so it was an excellent course for developing this approach
Spent a lot of time with logic at the start of the course, and then some work with combinatorics but primarily graph theory.
Topology, Graph Theory, and Counting
I learned mainly graph theory concepts.
This class was an ok introduction to discrete math, but the overall organization of class was not conducive to learning.
I learned proof-based thinking and mathematical concepts, such as the properties of graphs and counting techniques.
Proofs by induction, contradiction, counting, set theory, graph theory
I learned how to prove theorems and this problem solving ability will help in other aspects of life.
We learned about combinatorics, the principle of inclusion and exclusion, graph theory, and basic math concepts like injective and surjective functions, basic proof writing, etc.
Learned the fundamentals of discrete mathematics and proper proof writing
How to write proofs, a lot about graphs, and some basic combinatorics.
Introduction to a scattering of discrete mathematics topics: graph theory, counting, estimation
Discrete math

D.D. once forgot the name of this class while writing on the blackboard. I thought it might've been the first joke he made all year, but truly, he was not joking (surprise surprise). Upon being told the name, he responded, "Discrete Math? That can't be right," to the dismay of literally the entire class. For these reasons and more, I do not recommend you take Finite Math with Daniel Douglas.
how to think logically... how to write proofs

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I believe this course could be organized better with more frequent posting of the lecture notes and such.
We didn't cover enough content. I would have liked to get through Ramsey's theorem, at least.
The course was a little disorganized and slowly paced at the beginning, but it improved a lot over the semester.
organized, interesting material

This way this class is structured is very organized and intuitive; first, we start with sets theory and counting, then we move onto graphs for the remainder of the semester. However, I think set theory could have been tied in a bit more into graph theory.

The course excels in delving the student into new material on a weekly basis and challenging them with every problem. The one huge weakness of this course is the book. The book is massively difficult to read and feels pretty condescending to the beginner in discrete math.
Lectures super useless, but the textbook is really good and has interesting problems.

Strengths: material is fun if you enjoy high school math competitions; exams were fair

Weaknesses: the professor is extremely disorganized, with many issues with pset and exam grading and course notes
I think this course spent much more time on various topics related to logic and graph theory but ultimately did not cover as much content as the course previously did.
I think the teaching was poor and unorganized, and could benefit from leaning away from the textbook and more toward the teacher's interests.
The class was well taught, easy to follow.

Problem sets were somewhat inconsistent, so it can be a little hard to get into a schedule. Additionally problems on problem sets were sometimes inconsistent with the type of content we would even need to know for exams.

Strength: prof was very helpful in office hours

Weaknesses: lectures werent super well organized, not many resources apart from office hours, exam prep was minimal
I would've preferred if we covered more of the interesting content later on in the textbook rather than focusing on 'random' topics such as configuration spaces.

The course strictly followed the textbook and we didnt get to learn Ramsey Theorem or Stirling Numbers. However, I think I have a good fundamental understanding of the content that we covered such as combinatorics and graph theory.

The content for this course is interesting and a nice way to ease into proof-based math, but as a 3rd year math student, I was pretty bored. We went pretty slowly, and we didn't approach the subject matter with a lot of rigor. I don't want to say make it harder, but it felt like we could have gotten through a lot more material.
Have a consistent professor teaching it.

I think overall it was a great class that taught a lot, but I think it could benefit from some more organization near the beginning of the semester (following more closely with the book, especially with problem sets). I think there could be a lot more clarity in review material and practice/study material as well.

The course content is engaging, especially if you are interested in learning about graphs and how to write rigorous proofs, which are expected of in higher level math courses.

The class was poorly timed; we had weekly Psets that were due on Friday, but the course always lagged behind schedule so it was only after Wednesday that we learned what we needed to solve the Pset. Grading was generally slow, and so was the course note updates.
Although Dan matured into a more effective teacher, at the beginning of the semester he was very hesitant and the course was relatively unorganized throughout.

Strength: The professor fundamentally cares about the students.
Weakness: lecture is sometimes not very organized

May Yale abolish the Gibbs Assistant Professorship forever so poor peasants like me may no longer suffer the wrath, tyranny, and excruciating boredom of research topologists trying to teach first-principle proofs to teenagers.

strengths: a LOT of support... prof. douglas' office hours and the peer tutors were great and they were really really helpful in solving some extremely challenging psets... prof. douglas is a very kind person! weaknesses: the material was really really challenging and some of the problems we did in the psets really felt like they needed a stroke of genius (it would be really hard to rely only on the lectures)... the type of course material is honestly really challenging to explain so lectures were confusing at times... professor douglas could have DEFINITELY been more organized with the online lecture uploads as well, they really messed up my study schedule when a friday class would be cancelled only for him to upload a recorded makeup lecture on sunday evening.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would not recommend this course and I believe 202 might be a better choice.
Useful introduction to graph theory.
Yes, but maybe not as your first proof based math class.
yes

I would definitely recommend this course to another student. It provides a very good foundational knowledge for future classes, especially for computer science, and it also teaches you a lot about mathematical conventions and proof writing.

I would not recommend the course if you don't have experience in writing proofs. The prereq is MATH 115 but I think you need some form of proof experience. Otherwise, sure because its probably major req.
I would recommend this course to another student once they have taken many 200-level courses. This one is enormously challenging for those unfamiliar with formal mathematics.
Loved the topic, so I loved the course
Take it for the major I guess, just don't expect to get much out of the lectures
If youre interested in high school math competitions or would like a more rigorous, mathematical understanding of some CS concepts, take this course
I thin most students who take this course are required to for CS. I definitely would recommend it over the CPSC 202 if you are willing to write proofs.
Yes, it is relatively straight forward and quite useful.

No, I think the material could be interesting, but I took this because it was a requirement. I was initially intrigued, but I was really dissuaded by the teacher and his lack of ability to explain things clearly.
It is a very fun course that I would recommend
Probably not if you dont have to take it.
If you have to take discrete math, yes, but try not to take it with Dan Douglas.

Yes, but only if it isnt their first math class; I dont think this class is a good introduction to proofs; rather, it would be a better class to further improve mathematical thinking. Dont really understand how it serves as a prerequisite for learning CS though (apart from estimations)
I would recommend this course for any CS majors, and for people who want a math course without too much workload
It depends on the professor because each one has a different curriculum.
I would. The math is good to know, and for someone who doesn't know how to write proofs, this is a good place to start.
Yeah, discrete is conceptually kind of fun to think about and for the most part intuitive. The class definitley couldve covered more, but what we covered was cool enough
No, I felt the teacher was poor.
Yes, it is both a great class to understand mathematics and proof writing, as well as an understandable requirement for computer science/math majors.
I would recommend this course to anyone who wants to learn about graphs and proof writing. This is also a requirement for CS and Math majors.
It will definitely be better as the instructor gets more experience but not in its current state
Yes, if you wanna learn more about logic, counting, graph, writing proof, etc
Hell no.
not... really... unless you need it. so many people dropped the class (iirc about 20% did before the final) and the challenge is quite a lot for a course if not taken for a major requirement
